articles.headline: As Amazon Fires Become Global Crisis, Brazil’s President Reverses Course
articles.snippet: After days of playing down the fires raging across the Amazon, President Bolsonaro orders the military to step in. But it’s not clear that will be enough.
articles.abstract: After days of playing down the fires raging across the Amazon, President Bolsonaro orders the military to step in. But it’s not clear that will be enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — As an ecological disaster in the Amazon escalated into a global political crisis, Brazil’s president, Jair Bolsonaro, took the rare step on Friday of mobilizing the armed forces to help contain blazes of a scale not seen in nearly a decade.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño, Manuela Andreoni and Letícia Casado

articles.headline: Your Long-Term Care Insurance Rate Spiked. Now What?
articles.snippet: Long-ago miscalculations by insurers have led to policyholders’ facing steep premium increases. But there are ways to keep costs down.
articles.abstract: Long-ago miscalculations by insurers have led to policyholders’ facing steep premium increases. But there are ways to keep costs down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karen Herzog, a retired high school teacher, bought a long-term care insurance policy 12 years ago because she didn’t want to burden her only daughter if someday she could no longer care for herself.

articles.headline: A Gyrating Economy, and Trump’s Volatile Approach to It, Raise Alarms
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s wild pronouncements on Friday renewed questions about his stewardship of the world’s largest economy even as he escalated a trade war with China before heading to France for the G7 summit.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s wild pronouncements on Friday renewed questions about his stewardship of the world’s largest economy even as he escalated a trade war with China before heading to France for the G7 summit.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIARRITZ, France — President Trump has again tossed out the economic and political playbook that guided other occupants of the Oval Office for generations as the United States dominated the flow of goods and services across the world.

articles.headline: Trump Asserts He Can Force U.S. Companies to Leave China
articles.snippet: The president cited a national security law from 1977 that has never before been used to cut economic ties with a major power in a trade dispute.
articles.abstract: The president cited a national security law from 1977 that has never before been used to cut economic ties with a major power in a trade dispute.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIARRITZ, France — President Trump asserted on Saturday that he has the authority to make good on his threat to force all American businesses to leave China, citing a national security law that has been used mainly to target terrorists, drug traffickers and pariah states like Iran, Syria and North Korea.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Trade Turmoil Gives Democrats an Opening to Hit Trump on Economy
articles.snippet: Democratic candidates have taken a calibrated approach to talking about the economy, but the trade war with China provides a potent new line of attack.
articles.abstract: Democratic candidates have taken a calibrated approach to talking about the economy, but the trade war with China provides a potent new line of attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Weeks of turmoil in financial markets and an extraordinary outburst over trade from President Trump have opened a fresh lane of attack for Democrats hoping to unseat a president who has put the strength of the economy at the center of his re-election pitch.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: How American Gun Laws Are Fueling Jamaica’s Homicide Crisis
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of guns sold in the United States vanish because of loose American gun laws. Many reappear on the Caribbean island, turning its streets into battlefields.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of guns sold in the United States vanish because of loose American gun laws. Many reappear on the Caribbean island, turning its streets into battlefields.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLARENDON, Jamaica — She came to Jamaica from the United States about four years ago, sneaking in illegally, stowed away to avoid detection. Within a few short years, she became one of the nation’s most-wanted assassins.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: The Education of Elizabeth Warren
articles.snippet: The former law professor’s path to presidential contender began in Texas bankruptcy courts, where she witnessed desperate families, similar to her own.
articles.abstract: The former law professor’s path to presidential contender began in Texas bankruptcy courts, where she witnessed desperate families, similar to her own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Never one to shy away from a fight, Elizabeth Warren had found a new sparring partner. She had only recently started teaching at the University of Texas School of Law, but her colleague Calvin H. Johnson already knew her well enough to brace for a lively exchange as they commuted to work.

articles.headline: Iceland’s Purple Planes Are Grounded, and With Them, Its Economy
articles.snippet: The collapse of WOW Air, the discount airline, has damaged the country’s tourism industry, which had lifted it from the wreckage of the 2008 financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The collapse of WOW Air, the discount airline, has damaged the country’s tourism industry, which had lifted it from the wreckage of the 2008 financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — In retrospect, it was probably not a fantastic idea to leave Iceland’s economic fortunes tethered to an airline called WOW.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Nissan Got Rid of Carlos Ghosn. The Way It Did So May Prove Costly.
articles.snippet: The Japanese carmaker’s public accounting of its internal problems could provide a handy road map for lawyers seeking payback for investor losses.
articles.abstract: The Japanese carmaker’s public accounting of its internal problems could provide a handy road map for lawyers seeking payback for investor losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the arrest last year of its chairman, Carlos Ghosn, Nissan has made a very public accounting of its management failures, from a lack of strong internal checks and balances to board meetings that lasted only 20 minutes.

articles.headline: Trump Allies Target Journalists Over Coverage Deemed Hostile to White House
articles.snippet: A loose network of conservatives says it has dossiers of offensive social media posts and other problematic public statements by hundreds of journalists.
articles.abstract: A loose network of conservatives says it has dossiers of offensive social media posts and other problematic public statements by hundreds of journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A loose network of conservative operatives allied with the White House is pursuing what they say will be an aggressive operation to discredit news organizations deemed hostile to President Trump by publicizing damaging information about journalists.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Trump Faces a Stubborn Opponent in Fed’s Economic Experts
articles.snippet: As the president attacks the Federal Reserve, policymakers are looking the other way — and closing ranks around the Fed chair, Jerome H. Powell.
articles.abstract: As the president attacks the Federal Reserve, policymakers are looking the other way — and closing ranks around the Fed chair, Jerome H. Powell.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Wyo. — President Trump characterizes himself as a master deal maker who gets what he wants. But as he tries to pressure the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, he is contending with a powerful opponent: technocrats.

articles.headline: Trump’s Signature New York Hotel and the Art of the Compromise
articles.snippet: Facing demands to change the name of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, the president’s business is considering signage that would elevate its Central Park West address.
articles.abstract: Facing demands to change the name of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, the president’s business is considering signage that would elevate its Central Park West address.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, the Trump International Hotel and Tower has soared over Central Park, a crown jewel of President Trump’s family business that features luxury hotel rooms and exclusive private residences just off Columbus Circle.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Trump Offers Contradictory Signals on China Trade War
articles.snippet: After initially said that he was having “second thoughts” about a new levies on Chinese goods, Mr. Trump said he only regretted not raising tariffs faster.
articles.abstract: After initially said that he was having “second thoughts” about a new levies on Chinese goods, Mr. Trump said he only regretted not raising tariffs faster.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIARRITZ, France — President Trump offered deeply contradictory signals about his trade war with China on Sunday, ending the day by escalating his threats of higher tariffs even as he remained isolated from fellow world leaders on a strategy that has rattled the global economy.

articles.headline: Billy Bush Is Ready for a Return to TV. Will Viewers Welcome Him Back?
articles.snippet: A fireball producer is giving him a comeback chance while also trying to revive the tired celebrity news genre. It’s Mr. Bush’s first TV job since the infamous “Access Hollywood” tape.
articles.abstract: A fireball producer is giving him a comeback chance while also trying to revive the tired celebrity news genre. It’s Mr. Bush’s first TV job since the infamous “Access Hollywood” tape.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — The television producer Lisa Gregorisch-Dempsey is known for her terrifying candor. The nameplate on her desk at Telepictures, where she has run the celebrity news show “Extra” for 19 years, sums up her style: “I’ll be nicer if you’ll be smarter.” But even her longtime lieutenants were a bit startled by the way she laid it on the line for Billy Bush when she interviewed him for a job last year.

articles.headline: The Sisters Who First Tried to Take Down Jeffrey Epstein
articles.snippet: Nine years before any police investigation, Maria and Annie Farmer reported the troubling behavior of Jeffrey Epstein and his companion, Ghislaine Maxwell. No one would act.
articles.abstract: Nine years before any police investigation, Maria and Annie Farmer reported the troubling behavior of Jeffrey Epstein and his companion, Ghislaine Maxwell. No one would act.
articles.lead_paragraph: As more women have come forward in recent days to describe assaults at the hands of Jeffrey Epstein, Maria Farmer finds herself distraught, wondering what might have happened if someone had taken her seriously.

articles.headline: Inside North Carolina’s Big Effort to Transform Health Care
articles.snippet: The state and its top insurer are pushing to pay health care providers based on whether they keep people healthy, not for each service they provide.
articles.abstract: The state and its top insurer are pushing to pay health care providers based on whether they keep people healthy, not for each service they provide.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — North Carolina seems like an unlikely laboratory for health care reform. It refused to expand Medicaid coverage under the Affordable Care Act, and ranks in the bottom third among states in measures of overall health.
